author: vgr2774
content: If we look at the actual data regarding validators (Solo, CEX related, Others) we can already see that CEX related validator market share is high. There are lots of people who can't afford to run a solo validator or don't want to go through the effort to run a node but still want to stake their ETH. Like it or not, these people look at the options available and will mostly put financial incentives before the health of the network. Assuming that RP launches as-is, CEX'es would only have to share a fraction of the MEV/coinbase rewards to have a serious advantage over decentralized pools. 0x02 partially solves this problem because at least there's a fair distribution of the coinbase rewards to all actors in the pool. Wouldn't we rather have these people consider joining a decentralized pool as a node operator or as a regular staker where we have 1 human per validator instead of 1 company for all validators?

author: jgm
content:
There are some serious tax considerations here.  Swapping one asset (ETH) for another (staked ETH) is considered a disposal in many jurisdictions.  Lots of people have ignored this, in a "they kind-of look the same if you turn your head sideways and squint" manner, but it's going to cause some major problems when the tax authorities come calling.

(This isn't a problem for everyone, but _e.g._ long-term holders will not want to expose themselves to this.)

author: greg7mdp
content:
Except that if the RP node operators pocket all the coinbase, and CEXs share some of it with their stakers, it will be more attractive for small holders to stake with CEXs, thereby killing RP staking (as the RP node operators won't get the 16 eth needed to complete their node).

Without 0x02, RP is at the mercy of the first CEX who decides to share some of the coinbase revenue in order to kill RP, and this would remove the only possibility for small holders to stake in a decentralized way.

author: jasper.the.friendly.ghost
content: The world in which there are only solo stakers or centralized pools is a losing one for solo stakers, *even without MEV.* Clearly economies of scale support centralized pools if MEV is allowed. However, as others suggest, economies of scale with liquid staking will create opportunities for centralized pools to offer higher returns per ETH. I contend that in these universes, solo staking falls to pools. We can think of the pool stakers (<32 ETH) as just capital looking to go somewhere. This capital has no option for staking except for DeFi (providing limited ETH security) or CEX staking (undesirable security).  This capital going to CEXs is bad for solo stakers as it increases the power of liquid staking further.

author: vgr2774
content: And that can't be the case if we can't share the coinbase rewards with every actor on the decentralized pool. Because if CEX solutions have this option & offer better rewards (e.g. sharing part of the extracted MEV) then decentralized pools won't stand a chance.

author: vgr2774
content: If people have to choose between having X(X)% less rewards but helping decentralise the network or having more rewards and go with a CEX option, you can be sure that most of them will be choosing the CEX option. I can't see CEX staking going away any time soon. So if there's a chance to level the playing field for the decentralized option, I think less people would choose the CEX option. This is only valid if the attack vector for the decentralized pool is limited. For Rocketpool, it's 16 eth to run a node but that's still a large investment for a lot people and every validator is actually run by a human being. While every eth staked on CEX alternatives is an eth more that 1 company/entity can potentially use to attack the network. I agree it's the lesser of 2 evils but imo it's still decentralized. Every validator on RocketPool is up because someone put in the effort to make it up & running, maintain it, guarantee uptime and put in a sizable amount of capital.

author: paniczone
content:
I think "moving to pools" may be an inadvertently misleading phrase, in proof of work pools are all centralised by nature with only one entity in the middle observing the blockchain and posting blocks, thats not how a 
decentralised pool works under proof of stake at all. An individual with 64 ETH instead deciding to run 4 rocketpool nodes isn't "moving to a pool", the pool is moving to him and his political power over the network is increased with ETH that otherwise would have gone to the centralised pool which can be more thought of as a traditional pool

author: paniczone
content:
While decentralised staking may multiply the political power of individual centralised staking pools who decide to use it, it does not multiply the political power of centralised staking as a whole, as most decentralised staking depositors would deposited to a centralised solution otherwise. 
On the other hand, decentralised staking does multiply the political power of individual stakers as a whole, as they are able to spin up more nodes with the ETH that would have been on a centralised pool otherwise
This is what "moving to a pool" means in this case and I think it should be encouraged
